awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Developing A 3D Total Body Imaging and Analysis System for Early Detection of Skin Cancer
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a high-speed and high-precision 3D imaging and skin analysis system. Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the US, with 5.5 million new cases diagnosed in 2019. Research shows that skin cancers are highly treatable if detected early. Early detection of melanoma saves lives and improves the treatment outcomes by reducing the risk of spreading cancer to other parts of the body. Early detection of nonmelanoma skin cancers minimizes disfigurement and enhances the quality of life and productivity for many patients. The proposed technology may be a new tool for dermatologists and make skin cancer screening more affordable by optimizing the skin evaluation process, supporting teledermatology services, and lowering the overall costs of care. In addition, there may be other applications of this 3D imaging technology in skin evaluation for cosmetic product development, planning and evaluation of orthodontic and cosmetic procedures, real-time monitoring of radiotherapy patients, facial expression and virtual character creation for movie and virtual reality game productions, and dynamic facial recognition for identity and property protection.   

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a high-speed, high-accuracy 3D scanner using multi-wavelength, phase-shifting structured light and an automated skin analysis software using computational conformal geometry. The proposed 3D scanner is designed to capture the human body’s geometry at high speed (up to 180 frames/second) and with high precision (depth resolution of 0.2mm). Visual identification of skin changes in 2D is impractical. When the viewing angle is altered, the individual’s posture varies, or the surface is deformed, image registration becomes challenging and unstable. The proposed solution is based on extensive research in computational conformal geometry. Due to the shape-preserving property of conformal mapping, 3D geometric analysis may be accomplished by processing 2D conformal images, which is easier and faster. Independent of their geometric or topological complexities, shapes in real physical worlds may be conformally transformed into one of three canonical shapes (i.e., unit sphere, Euclidean plane, or planar disk). Because of the uniformity, the design of all geometric algorithms can be simplified, resulting in dramatically improved efficiency, accuracy, and robustness. By combining high-performance 3D scanning and advanced conformal mapping techniques, this foundational platform technology may enable many applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
With the support of NSF, Orchid Imaging team has achieved the following outcomes:

Precision 3D Facial Imaging System: Orchid3D camera system combines stereo-vision and structured light techniques for capturing skin surface texture and geometry with speed and accuracy. A unified algorithm optimizes depth information and phase unwrapping using Markov random field approach, ensuring robustness even in noisy conditions. Bidirectional feedback between high- and low-level vision tasks enhances accuracy, meeting technical requirements for high-speed (up to 60 frames/second) and high-precision (0.15mm depth resolution) capturing.

3D Registration and Facial Soft Tissue Analysis Software: The software integrates image processing and geometry analysis methods, utilizing computer vision techniques and computational conformal geometry. It registers facial surface geometry and skin texture, generating point clouds for analysis. Techniques like Teichmuller mapping enable surface registration and dynamic tracking, facilitating automated landmark mapping and shape classification.

Clinical Evaluation: Orchid3D system enables precise clinical evaluation of facial soft tissue aesthetics pre- and post-Orthopedic Maxillary Expansion (OME) treatment, addressing deficiencies in conventional methods. IRB-approved studies at SBU Dental School recruit orthodontic patients for OME treatment, aiming for statistical power in detecting changes. Soft tissue landmarks are identified and measured in 3D facial images, with data analyzed to examine differences and develop predictive models for treatment outcomes.

Customer Discovery and Technology Commercialization: Orchid Imaging pivoted from skin cancer screening to a service-based revenue model for 3D imaging services in dermatology. Identifying opportunities in skincare product testing and orthodontics, Orchid collaborated with Stony Brook Medicine to validate market fit, projecting significant serviceable markets. Licensing agreements and exploration of health tech accelerator programs aim to facilitate technology commercialization, with plans for promotion post-wrinkle study completion.

 


Last Modified: 03/25/2024
Modified by: Xianfeng Gu
